data.question: Can you provide practice problems on multiplying two matrices?

docs.title: 674dcdb4b00b977d048c931b
docs.text: The admission tickets to the Singapore Zoo are $50 for an adult, $36 for a child, and $20 for a senior citizen. On a particular Tuesday, there were 212 adults, 251 children, and 15 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo and on a particular Wednesday, there were 231 adults, 266 children, and 12 senior citizens who visited the Singapore Zoo. The number of visitors on the particular Tuesday and Wednesday can be represented by the matrix V = \begin{pmatrix} 212 & 251 & 15 \\ 231 & 266 & 12 \end{pmatrix}. \text{ (i) Write a } 3 \times 1 \text{ matrix, P, to represent the price of the admission tickets. (ii) Find the matrix } T = VP. \text{ (iii) Explain what each of the elements represents. (iv) Find the total amount collected from the sales of the tickets for the 2 days.}

docs.title: 674dcde1b00b977d048c9352
docs.text: Two outlets of a coffee chain sell three different types of coffee: espresso, flat white and mocha. The table shows the number of cups of each type of coffee sold on a particular day. Outlet A: Espresso 30, Flat White 30, Mocha 35; Outlet B: Espresso x, Flat White x + 2, Mocha 40. This information can be represented by the matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 30 & 30 & 35 \\ x & x+2 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \). The coffee chain sells a cup of espresso at $2.50, a cup of flat white at $4 and a cup of mocha at $5.50. This information can be represented by the matrix \( Q = \begin{pmatrix} 2.5 \\ 4 \\ 5.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (a) Find, in terms of x, the matrix \( R = PQ \).

docs.title: 674dce0fb00b977d048c9395
docs.text: (c) Evaluate the matrix G = LC.

By using matrix multiplication, calculate the total amount of money the dance school earns for this 10-week block of sessions.

docs.text: Jane exchanged 500 Singapore dollars ($) into Thai baht (THB) when the exchange rate was $1 = 26.77 THB. She travelled to Thailand and spent 10,600 THB. On her return to Singapore, she exchanged the remaining Thai baht into dollars with the exchange rate $1 = 26.88 THB. Calculate the amount she received in dollars. Correct your answer to the nearest cent.

data.output: A bookstore sells stationary items in three categories: pens, notebooks, and erasers. On a given Monday, Shop Alpha sold 45 pens, 60 notebooks, and 25 erasers; Shop Beta sold 55 pens, 70 notebooks, and y erasers. This data can be represented with the matrix \( S = \begin{pmatrix} 45 & 60 & 25 \\ 55 & 70 & y \end{pmatrix} \). The cost of each item is as follows: pens cost $1.5, notebooks cost $2.5, and erasers cost $0.5. This information can be displayed in a 3x1 matrix \( C = \begin{pmatrix} 1.5 \\ 2.5 \\ 0.5 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Compute the total revenue generated by each shop using the matrix multiplication \( R = SC \). (ii) Interpret the resulting matrix R in terms of the revenue from each shop.

data.output:
In a local amusement park, the ticket prices for different age groups on weekdays are as follows: $45 for adults, $30 for teenagers, and $18 for children. On Thursday, 190 adults, 220 teenagers, and 45 children visited, while on Friday, 205 adults, 240 teenagers, and 40 children visited. Represent the number of visitors on Thursday and Friday in a matrix, \( V = \begin{pmatrix} 190 & 220 & 45 \\ 205 & 240 & 40 \end{pmatrix} \).

(i) Write a \( 3 \times 1 \) matrix, \( P \), to represent the ticket prices for adults, teenagers, and children.
(ii) Calculate the matrix \( T = VP \).
(iii) Interpret the meaning of each element in the matrix \( T \).
(iv) Determine the total revenue generated from ticket sales over these two days.

data.output: A bookstore sells three types of books: Fiction, Non-Fiction, and Science. The number of each type of book sold across two branches on a weekend is as follows. Branch 1: Fiction 120, Non-Fiction 210, Science 75; Branch 2: Fiction y, Non-Fiction 2y - 10, Science 85. Represent this information with the matrix \( B = \begin{pmatrix} 120 & 210 & 75 \\ y & 2y - 10 & 85 \end{pmatrix} \). If each Fiction book is sold at $15, each Non-Fiction at $22, and each Science book at $30, this can be represented by the matrix \( C = \begin{pmatrix} 15 \\ 22 \\ 30 \end{pmatrix} \). (i) Determine, in terms of y, the matrix \( D = BC \). (ii) Explain the meaning of each entry in matrix \( D \). (iii) Calculate the total revenue from the sales of books over the weekend, assuming \( y = 130 \).

data.output:
An amusement park has three types of visitors: adults, teenagers, and children. The entrance fees for each group are $60 for adults, $45 for teenagers, and $30 for children. On a sunny Saturday, the park was visited by 200 adults, 150 teenagers, and 100 children. On the following Sunday, the park received 180 adults, 170 teenagers, and 130 children. Represent the numbers of visitors over the weekend using the matrix \( V = \begin{pmatrix} 200 & 150 & 100 \\ 180 & 170 & 130 \end{pmatrix} \). 
(i) Define a \(3 \times 1\) matrix \( P \) to represent the price of admission for each visitor category. 
(ii) Compute the matrix \( T = VP \). 
(iii) Explain the meaning of each entry in the matrix \( T \). 
(iv) Calculate the total revenue generated from the ticket sales over these two days.

data.output:
Pineapple Paradise, a local fruit market, sells three varieties of citrus fruits: oranges, lemons, and grapefruits. On one busy weekend, the sales data was collected for two days. On Friday, 150 oranges, 175 lemons, and 20 grapefruits were sold, and on Saturday, 180 oranges, 210 lemons, and 25 grapefruits were sold. This can be represented by the matrix:

\[
V = \begin{pmatrix}
150 & 175 & 20 \\
180 & 210 & 25
\end{pmatrix}
\]

The prices for each fruit type are as follows: $1.25 per orange, $0.75 per lemon, and $1.50 per grapefruit, represented by the matrix:

\[
P = \begin{pmatrix}
1.25 \\
0.75 \\
1.50
\end{pmatrix}
\]

(i) Calculate the matrix \( T = VP \).
(ii) Interpret the elements of matrix \( T \).
(iii) Find the total revenue generated from the sales over these two days.
